customer_name: Wilson Horse and Mule Sale Inc

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
On March 7, 2025, at approx. 12:15 PM, a young aoudad (Lot # 2409) was observed by inspectors in its holding pen as
laying down with head up and alert to surroundings. When it attempted to rise from the ground, it was unable to move it’s
hind end into a standing position and continued to lay on the ground with the legs stretched out from the body. At the time
of observation by the inspectors, the facility was not aware of this animal’s condition. Subsequently the auction notified
the Attending Veterinarian (AV) via text. The AV responded via text at 2 PM and prescribed pain relief until their arrival at
the facility. The AV arrived at the facility at approx. 7:50 PM and elected humane euthanasia due to the severity of the
injury (diagnosed as a broken left rear leg and a broken back).
Identification of the issue, emergency care, and diagnosis of the downed animal’s condition were not provided in a timely
manner which led to the prolonged suffering of the animal.
Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include: The use of
appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the availability of emergency,
weekend, and holiday care.
Correct by: end of auction day on March 7, 2025. Corrected prior to exit interview.

During inspection on March 6 and 7, 2025, numerous members of the public were observed walking through the barns
and walkways between holding pens, reaching through the primary enclosures and touching many species of animals
waiting to be auctioned or already auctioned.
- On March 6 and 7, 2025, numerous members of the public were observed walking throughout the auction
grounds. Insufficient numbers of auction personnel and/or inadequate public barriers allowed the public to reach the
animals, including a variety of hoofstock, like sheep, goats, nilgai, eland, camels, llamas and alpacas. Several children
and adults were observed reaching through the holding pens to touch the animals. There were no auction personnel
observing these interactions, as well as no barrier preventing such interactions.
Public barriers and/or facility personnel are required to protect the public and animals from inappropriate interaction and
possible harm to the public and/or the animals.
During public exhibition, any animal must by handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.
Correct by: April 7, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
MARY ANN MCBRIDE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
On March 7, 2025, at approx. 12:15 PM, a young aoudad (Lot # 2409) was observed by inspectors in its holding pen as 
laying down with head up and alert to surroundings. When it attempted to rise from the ground, it was unable to move it’s 
hind end into a standing position and continued to lay on the ground with the legs stretched out from the body. At the time 
of observation by the inspectors, the facility was not aware of this animal’s condition. Subsequently the auction notified 
the Attending Veterinarian (AV) via text. The AV responded via text at 2 PM and prescribed pain relief until their arrival at 
the facility. The AV arrived at the facility at approx. 7:50 PM and elected humane euthanasia due to the severity of the 
injury (diagnosed as a broken left rear leg and a broken back).  
 
Identification of the issue, emergency care, and diagnosis of the downed animal’s condition were not provided in a timely 
manner which led to the prolonged suffering of the animal.  
 
Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include: The use of 
appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries, and the availability of emergency, 
weekend, and holiday care.  
 
Correct by: end of auction day on March 7, 2025. Corrected prior to exit interview. 
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
During inspection on March 6 and 7, 2025, numerous members of the public were observed walking through the barns 
and walkways between holding pens, reaching through the primary enclosures and touching many species of animals 
waiting to be auctioned or already auctioned.  
 
-  On March 6 and 7, 2025, numerous members of the public were observed walking throughout the auction 
grounds. Insufficient numbers of auction personnel and/or inadequate public barriers allowed the public to reach the 
animals, including a variety of hoofstock, like sheep, goats, nilgai, eland, camels, llamas and alpacas. Several children 
and adults were observed reaching through the holding pens to touch the animals. There were no auction personnel

observing these interactions, as well as no barrier preventing such interactions.  
 
Public barriers and/or facility personnel are required to protect the public and animals from inappropriate interaction and 
possible harm to the public and/or the animals.  
 
During public exhibition, any animal must by handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals 
and the public.  
 
Correct by: April 7, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
MARY ANN MCBRIDE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
